title: Before 1 January 2022, will President Biden invite Prime Minister Boris Johnson to visit the White House?
preds: After BBC (https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-58613389) and Sky News (https://news.sky.com/story/cop26-boris-johnson-to-travel-to-un-and-white-house-to-push-for-climate-action-ahead-of-crunch-summit-12411852), The Guardian, too, reports that BJ will meet Biden & Harris at the White House this week: https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2021/sep/19/boris-johnson-to-address-amazons-tax-record-with-jeff-bezos-on-us-visit

The BBC is reporting the visit to the White House too now.
BBC News - Boris Johnson to call for climate action during US visit
https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-58613389

There has been a scarcity of news and updates on this, but today both BBC and Sky News report that BJ will indeed visit the White House next week:
https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-58613389
https://news.sky.com/story/cop26-boris-johnson-to-travel-to-un-and-white-house-to-push-for-climate-action-ahead-of-crunch-summit-12411852

With the recent report I'll go full bars just in case, if it doesn't happen after the general assembly meeting I'll dial back heavily. https://www.standard.co.uk/news/politics/boris-johnson-joe-biden-white-house-meeting-next-week-b955819.html

Seems like it’s happening.  Ausuk likely the topic and or the cause. https://www.standard.co.uk/news/politics/boris-johnson-joe-biden-white-house-meeting-next-week-b955819.html I also missed the UNGA taking place in NY which was an opportunity to visit when ‘in town’.  Well done those who saw this 5 days earlier, I dropped the ball on this one.
France spat over Aussie nuke sub not helping
Very strong French backlash that makes this more difficult. Still another opportunity for invite after climate summit in Nov.
Does a meeting require an invite?

I read that he's been invited.
https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2021-09-15/us-president-biden-to-host-uk-pm-boris-johnson-at-the-white-house-next-week-axios
Recent media reports would suggest a meeting is now likely to take place later this month

https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/uk-pm-johnson-hold-talks-with-biden-this-month-times-2021-09-12/
"Sept 12 (Reuters) - UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson will attempt to patch up Britain’s frayed relationship with U.S. President Joe Biden's administration at a White House meeting between the two leaders this month, The Times newspaper reported on Monday, citing sources on both sides. Johnson is expected to hold talks with Biden during a four-day trip to the U.S. for the UN general assembly, which starts in New York on Sept. 21, the report said."

I don't know if Johnson can come, but an invitation should be announced. Despite the fact Johnson is despicable, he still leads the country most tied to our own national security interests. Ignoring him can't go on much longer.

UK and US programmes for the remainder of 2021 seem fairly packed with more domestically focused agendas.  Traditional time period for visits has been and gone and COVID is still a consideration in both nations.  Out of season domestic visits (Blair to Bush prior to Iraq war, Brown & Obama during the financial crisis, Thatcher to Reagen in 1988 etc [1]) all seem to have some important international or geopolitical event to require them: nothing obvious on the calendar for the remainder of this year. Limited political need to foster bonhomie between either side (assuming by now that a sulky Boris has been told by Biden that post Brexit trade deals are, in fact, "at the back of the queue" as previously warned) and little evidence of a desire to project it given the recent UK parliamentary statements on Afghanistan. As such, starting very low on this. [1] https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-38720850
Per WH visit logs, visitor rate is ~10% of normal. Estimating there's at least a 50% chance of this impacting BJ visiting drops my estimate overall to half the base rate.
Base rate * number of days, discounting the next week since these are always (as far as I can tell) announced at least ~1 week in advance.

This is politics so let's forget what Biden thinks and consider what the US public think. If everyone thinks that Biden despises Johnson because he is a British Trump (and from many comments on here that seems accurate) then there is a perception that UK-US 'special' relationship is cooling and that this govt is failing to deliver strong diplomatic ties with key allies, hence failing as a government and as a president. If there are elections coming up, lets say congress in 14 months time, then this perception will matter.
How could Biden show that UK-US relations are stronger than ever? Maybe that when he is over in Glasgow, he says "hey BoJo, thanks for having me, you should drop round my place some time"
Comin' down, guys. Look out below.

This seems very unlikely due to a multitude of factors: Biden and Johnson have already met recently and will meet again before 2022, the coronavirus is likely to keep both leaders occupied domestically, no affinity between both leaders, the Afghanistan debacle that would likely come up if both met outside of a topic specific event (e.g., COP26) to the annoyance of both parties.
Given @Hesch assessment of meetings occuring mostly in June or September, and no announcement as of yet to a meeting plus general group consensus I increase negative likelihood to 8:4, or 2:1.

Base rate of approximately 1 visit per year (as cited by other users) implies c.33% chance given the proportion of the year remaining. 
Reduce that by c.10-15% to reflect US political environment/agenda and UK both likely to be focussed elsewhere, plus COVID related issues.
Highly unlikely, because of the diplomatic row that happened this past June.
I believe a invite may be offered but Boris Johnson will not accept that invitation.

Firstly, my reduction is based on the model I sometimes build in my head. If we had a 8/10 possibility, then adding one to our odds of 8:2 gives 8:3, which is approximately 72 percent. Given that Covid-19 has limited travel between countries for 18 months, and that the transatlantic task force has not been mentioned in months according to The Daily Telegraph we can assume that the likelihood has decreased.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_visits_to_the_United_States:_Europe#United_Kingdom
The previous meetings were mostly on June or September; so, I'd think either it has to happen in the coming weeks - which is highly unlikely- or next year.

Furthermore, there's a lot to focus on domestically (especially for Biden, whose approval rating is getting lower and lower)
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/biden-approval-rating/ Also found this interesting https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-38720850
[First meetings: US presidents and UK prime ministers]

A meeting is unlikely before Jan. An invite for a future meeting more likely.
At present both leaders want to downplay the Afghan debacle and being seen together would ignite that. We’re not close to a trade agreement and USfocus is Asia so what would be the benefit to either of a visit? Without a trade agreement or some big political alignment it would, at this time, be a wasted PR opportunity.

Covid is forcing many countries to focus inwards; to look at their own vaccination programmes, case loads, economic recovery etc, not to mention a rise in natural disasters. The UK has little to offer the States, so I think Biden will focus on more pressing matters at home, rather than state dinners etc.

I suspect Biden sees Johnson as a Trump clone and has said all he needs to say to Johnson at the UK G7 a couple of months ago. Hence, while it maybe polite, I cannot see it as being high on Biden's agenda. @Wildwood2000 / @MCowley / @SE_Meyer

The arguments supporting a "yes" outcome seem to center on ceremony and need. Meanwhile, the "no" arguments appear to focus on COVID protocols, strained relationships, alternative meeting venues, and timing.  As the Queen was extended the honor already, and the President visited London already, it seems that the ceremonial boxes have been checked. In terms of need to meet, it appears that virtual meetings are already underway and meetings at other locations are already scheduled. Therefore, my initial forecast will start low and I'll maintain this level until circumstances develop otherwise. Time decay of roughly 1% per week starting in October unless news of a meeting surfaces.

Base rate on actual visits is pretty low, about an average of 1 per year pre -trump: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_visits_to_the_United_States:_Europe#United_Kingdom So on that base rate we have 4 months left in the year so 33%. The threshold for an invite is lower than an actual visit which would push the probability up, but ongoing covid restrictions would push it lower. Note however, that the covid restrictions are EU and - per brexit - the UK is most definitely not in the EU.  Overall the fact that there hasn't been a head of state visit since 2017 is something I'm not sure how to handle - does it raise the odds or no? Mostly I think it shows the odds go lower when the two heads of state aren't politically aligned. And, to some extent, I think this logic holds with Biden. For example, he hadn't called the Australian PM regarding the Afghanistan pullout, and one explanation seems to be that Morrison is much more conservative. So in that vein, he might not be keen to invite Boris to the whitehouse.  All told I'm taking my base rate and knocking it down 5% due to delta concerns and another 7.5% due to Boris = 33-12.5% = 20.5%.

Highly unlikely. The US/UK can't be seen too often (UK at least) blatantly ignoring the 'covid rules' of sheltering in place. Boris still maintains optics. Plus there is the Afghanistan disaster with UK feeling slights by US on multiple fronts. Boris might not want to court the idea of a more 'society encompassed' opposition that might outnumber the recent covid protests etc

Unlikely I would say:
1. Biden hates the guy and who can blame him for that
2. The idea of a UK/US special relationship is a myth that the UK holds on to far more than the other way round
3. That said, Biden is more outward looking than Trump and he might well be happy to pat the UK poodle given his current challenges on world stage

Starting high because there is enough precedent, baseline must be around 80% since the 60s, Biden has promised to work with Nato and enough common ground aside from political differences.
10% assigned to imponderables, death, loss of power, etc.

The question seems to ask whether the ‘special relationship’ between the White House and Downing Street is a little strained.
 The Obama administration did not support Brexit because it undermined the liberal democratic international order and was driven by populism, sovereignty and Britain first sentiments. Similarly, the former US administration gained power through populism, America first and MAGA sentiments and was thus not too antagonistic towards Brexit. However, the new administration disapproved of the UK intention of breaching the international rule of law to resolve the Northern Ireland border issue. Add to this back drop the recent timing of US unilateral decision to withdraw from Afghanistan may have exacerbated the situation.
I think the etiquette of inviting the UK PM to the White House of a new President will be observed but I am not sure any significance should be attached as to when the invitation is presented, accepted or fulfilled.
COVID, they met this summer and will see each other again in November, base rates, etc.

The relationship is strained and our governments are currently at different points of the political spectrum. That said, Biden is fast proving his team are a pack of absolute imbeciles on the world stage. Ideology will be put to one side to show he's not too dangerous and old ties will be shown to still be in operation. A 'special relationship' roll-out shows Biden as capable of keeping some semblance of foreign policy nous. Boris will be pushing for same to complete a trade deal.

Given the situation in Afghanistan, pm Boris Johnson is going to want to meet with Biden to explore future options. In fact, if the situation in Afghanistan deteriorates further, this estimation will go up. Which is likely to happen, given how quickly the situation has developed. Especially since ISIS are now involved to a high degree. Given that the US president visits the UK every 2 years, and we can assume it's the other way around on the other years. we can assume that given the situation in Afghanistan, but the fact that the US president has already visited this year, we can keep an estimation of 80 percent for now. But if the situation worsens, then I will increase this prediction. US presidential visits to the UK https://uk.usembassy.gov/our-relationship/visits-of-presidents-of-the-united-states-to-the-united-kingdom/ Note: Apologies for poor writing, keys on my keyboard are broken.
Uk is no longer an international powerhouse
Bad feeling over Afghanistan withdrawal, NI situation.
When the news cycle settles after the departure from Afghanistan, Biden will be needing to improve his reputation. Meeting with other friendly leaders will benefit him.

I could  see the invitation happening at COP in Glasgow but, after the slapping Biden got in the House of Commons and the situation in Northern Ireland after Brexit, he may just let 'Global Britain' stew for a while.
Biden is not mentally fit to sit down with other world leaders. There is a higher probability that Johnson will meet with Harris in her new role as President.
The U.K. has raise its relationship profile with the US on matters of trade, security and national stability. It would do BoJo some good and Biden no harm.
Based on the number of times a PM has visited the US in the fall since 1929. Opportunity to better understand how many of those were to the white house.

No. The state of internal and external affairs both in the US and the UK is not conducive to a high level meeting between the POTUS and BPM. Absent a major crisis in which the US and UK may need each other's significant and urgent involvement I do not see them meeting in the next 4 months.
Very likely, as a key ally, and with Afghanistan and Covid, the need to meet is there, and Biden needs to soothe some of the recent wounds across our alliances.
He might invite but not enough time to arrange the actual visit this year

21 - 0 so far data from https://history.state.gov/departmenthistory/visits/united-kingdom average per year = 1.46 seems to depend on:
relationship between leaderships
geopolitical events
COVID restricting travel  other things:
both meeting in Glasgow for COP26, could invite him there, or deem that meeting enough.  by the end of this year, I think an Invitation  for the first half of next year is the most likely outcome (60%). But, will that visit be to the White House? Possibly as first visits often are, but there is a strong chance it isn't, esp with the logistics involved with COVID (65%).
busy fall schedule, covid, already have met and a possibly less than great personal relationship between the two. Invite coming later rather than sooner.
It will happen just before Johnson resigns later this year (2021)

It only takes an invite, not an actual visit, which gives a longer time horizon than the question first suggests. May visited in 2017. Cameron in 2015, 2012, 2010. Brown in '08 and '09.  Now that Biden has been there it seems likely Johnson will reciprocate. Covid has drastically reduced the frequency of state visits and is on the rise due to Delta. If delta seems stable in the fall this may trigger increased plans for 2022.   " Every year in Washington there are an average of six "state visits" where chiefs of state, presidents and royalty from around the globe come to the United States to meet with the American president." https://www.rferl.org/a/1086035.html I looked at a few years to see how many total white house visits happen in a given year. There were 32 visits in 2019. 9 in 2016. 24 in 2015. https://history.state.gov/departmenthistory/visits/united-kingdom I don't think its a certainty but there are some pressing mutual issues that may make it more likely. Since I'm sure it'll happen over Biden's term at some point I'll go slightly better than 1 in 3 to start.

I start with an outside view of 9% (days in question over days in a typical presidency) and adjust because it has happened before in the middle of December with Trump, so there may be more imperative for the new president to meet Johnson—since they haven't met at the White House yet. In addition, there is a possibility that the Afghanistan crisis forces these two to meet at the White House within the next year, with the UK discussing ways it can help especially with the refugees. On the other hand, one can argue that this crisis makes it even LESS likely that such an exlusive meeting will occur. Also, COVID.

Starting at 20%. Biden's recently seen Johnson in the UK, and presumably will see him again in November at the Climate Conference in Scotland.  Given the potential Delta resurgence it doesn't seem like the last months of 2021 is a great time for an invitation.  
Biden and Johnson talked on the phone Aug 17, and no invitation happened. Also it doesn't sound like there's a blossoming friendship - Biden doesn't seem happy about Brexit and Johnson's not happy about the Afghanistan withdrawl.   https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/08/17/readout-of-president-joseph-r-biden-jr-call-with-prime-minister-boris-johnson-of-the-united-kingdom-2/ https://www.express.co.uk/news/world/1482216/US-trade-deal-news-Joe-Biden-Boris-Johnson-Brexit-EU-exit-Afghanistan-Kabul https://www.independent.co.uk/asia/south-asia/afghanistan-taliban-joe-biden-boris-johnson-b1908103.html
This is the sort of cheap flattery that US presidents excel at and lads like BoJo are highly susceptible to.  Why not?
If we have a different president by then does their invitation count or has it got to be the current installed President.?
Hard to see how this special relationship bubbles to the top of a crowded list of priorities.
